data.title: Warning: skipFiles entries starting with '!' aren't supported and will be ignored.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use "!xxx" in skipfiles
2. Start project

Still having a great deal of trouble using `skipFiles` effectively. 

Config

```
"skipFiles": [
    "<node_internals>/**/*.js",
    "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/**/*.js"
    "!${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/@local/**/*.js"
],
```

```
Warning: skipFiles entries starting with '!' aren't supported and will be ignored. 
("!d:\Users\.../node_modules/@local/**/*.js")
```
Documentation:

https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/nodejs/nodejs-debugging

Example taken directly from documentation:

```
"skipFiles": [
    "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/**/*.js",
    "!${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/math/**/*.js"
]
```

So the documentation includes examples that use unsupported syntax. I'm not sure how else I would be expected to know how to use it.

data.title: [scss] error on string concatenation in URL
Disable git.autofetch by default
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.10.2 (1.10.2)
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install vscode

In my terminal, I show the number of commits I am behind upstream. For the last few weeks, every morning I've sat down at my terminal, that number has changed overnight. I was going bonkers trying to figure out what was doing it. Someone was touching git without my explicit instruction and I couldn't figure it out. I don't have any git plugins installed in vscode, and I don't have any git user settings, so it obviously couldn't be vscode, right?

Finally on a whim, after ruling out several command line tools, I searched vscode's default settings and found `git.autofetch`. Ah ha, this is the culprit. This should not be a default setting. I did not give vscode explicit permission to modify my local git code, and I had no way of debugging who was modifying my git setup.

data.title: Fix #23194
data.body:
This change uses `uri.with` to get a new version which has the same fields except no scheme. It also removes `paths.normalize` because the uri may be a URL, not a path, and that causes it to have \ on windows. I don't know if that's safe or if `paths.normalize` is needed in some case. I also don't know whether the `if (resource.scheme === 'debug')` check is necessary.

I think that embedding a URL or path or made up path like `<node_internals>/...` into a URI might be unsafe in other cases too, but I don't really know. Another approach would be to just `encodeURIComponent` the entire thing from the debugger, instead of trying to interpret it in vscode, and only decode it for display. I don't know whether there's anywhere that we need it to work like an actual URI?

1. Start a new terminal session with any terminal app
2. Run a command that writes output longer than the current terminal height
3. Attempt to scroll while selecting text with the moue
4. Can't select more than what's currently visible in the terminal

data.title: Improve the 'drag 'n drop' feature to up 'n down selected text
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->
The 'drag and drop' feature is one of the most requested requests by most popular IDE's users in this decade, such as Sublime Text and Atom. You have placed it as part of the configuration, and it is 'false' by default (that will already depend on each user, however, I would prefer it to be enabled by default).
However, they lacked to complement this functionality with this one: to allow, when the user select a text, by pressing ctrl + up / ctrl + down, he/she can respectively, up/down the text (as do the previously mentioned Sublime Text and Atom).

If you consider that this functionality is present, but not active, you can either make it active in a future minor update and, in contrast, close this request. Very thanks.

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2/Confirmation 8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331
- OS Version: Zorin OS 12 (Ubuntu-based 16.04)

data.title: typescript class jump to detention when there is constructor function
Add File Path to the Info Bar
data.body:
This is a new feature request.

Atom has a surprisingly convenient feature where the info bar at the bottom of the editor displays the relative file path ([screenshot](http://i.imgur.com/lTYiNYf.png)), and clicking on that path copies the full local path to your clipboard.  It's really convenient and I'd love to see it as a feature for vscode.  For VSCode, It might be able to go in blue status/info bar at the bottom of the editor.

Current version of vscode: 1.10.2
Extensions: Copy relative path, jsx, Material-theme, Perforce, Ruby, vscode-icon

data.title: Use different badge colors for modified and renamed files in git sidebar
data.body:
Please use different badge colors for modified and renamed files in the git sidebar to provide better visual distinction, which is important if there are lots of changes - especially upon merging. Right now both use blue color and visually hardly distinguishable.

I'd suggest orange color for some of them. :)

data.title: HTML minification doesn't work on child content that isn't tabbed within
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.10.2 (8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331, 2017-03-08T14:02:52.799Z) - OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393 - Extensions: |Extension|Author|Version| |---|---|---| |vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.8| |mssql|ms-mssql|0.3.0| |csharp|ms-vscode|1.8.0| |debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.7.1|; --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a HTML document 2. Add some code with `
` layout such as:
```
      

        
Links

        

          
This is a link

          

a {
  color: $color-red;
  text-decoration: none;

  &:hover,
  &:active,
  &:focus {
    text-decoration: underline;
  }
}
          

        

      

```
3. Press the [-] in the margin next to the `article` element to minimise it
4. End up with this outcome:
```
      
...
a {
  color: $color-red;
  text-decoration: none;

  &:hover,
  &:active,
  &:focus {
    text-decoration: underline;
  }
}
``` 5. Expected outcome: ```
...
``` It works fine if I indent the code, however when I do that it of course indents it on the web page too, which I don't want.

data.title: Typo "Golbal" instead of "Global" in Info message after saving Formatter Config
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 7 (Microsoft Windows [Version 6.1.7601])

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Press Ctrl + Shift + P and edit the "Formatter Config"
2. Make a change and press Ctrl + S to save.
3. Info message pops up at the top of the windows and reads "[Golbal] After editing the file, remember to Restart VScode"

"Golbal" should be "Global".
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/537115/24705065/3b132674-19d8-11e7-9f2a-b44d8f4ead04.png)

data.title: Display search results in a tab instead of the side bar
data.body:
I was talking to a colleague the other day and the only reason he's not using VS Code is because of how the search is implemented in VS Code and I have to agree with his opinion.

Both Sublime Text (which I'm used to) and Atom (the editor my colleague is using) feature a search tab. A search tab displays the results much more clearly given that there's much more space available to display them. Instead, VS Code displays them in a "small" side bar.

Yes, we can resize back and forth the side bar, but that's a bit annoying. It would be nice to have the search results displayed in a new tab similar to Sublime Text and Atom.

data.title: Allow extensions to add new entries to the activity bar
data.body:
I'm moving from Sublime Text and one of the things I miss is a project management feature. The [Project Manager](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=alefragnani.project-manager) extension seems to do the trick but it would be nice if it could be integrated into the activity bar.

Either that or implement a built-in project management feature into the Activity bar, if, for me reason, you don't want to allow extensions access to the Activity bar.

What do you guys think?

data.title: javascript format: disable insert space inside curly braces
data.body:
Since there are already some `javascript.format.insertSpace...` settings available in VSCode, I have a suggestion to add another one.

When I import with curly braces, a space is added before and after the "imported word":
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17981138/24702785/c17e0634-1a00-11e7-8560-3df17a21aa79.png)
While doing the same in WebStorm:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17981138/24702839/e730ec70-1a00-11e7-8e38-52f8b79c1225.png)

VSCode also inserts a space to returns:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17981138/24702977/7c7ca698-1a01-11e7-914e-55a4e82bd960.png)

Webstorm does provide a setting for this: "spaces within ES6 import/export braces" to toggle this behaviour. Is it possible to add this setting to VSCode as well?

data.title: Allow for [Completion|Symbol]Kind modifiers
data.body:
extracted from #2628

In completions and for symbols we allow to provide a kind which is mostly use to derive an icon. For instance `vscode.CompletionItemKind.Method`. This issue is about allowing to modify these kinds to expressing that something is a _"private member"_ or an _"abstract protected method"_

The idea is that we don't add more and more kinds, e.g no `CompletionItemKind.PrivateMethod` but a second type, a kind-modifier, that works in combination with a kind.

Potential candidates are: _public, protected, internal, package-private, friend, private, static, final, const, abstract, volatile, transient, ..._ A "n languages have this"-rule should be applied when picking candidates.

data.title: Use diff3 for showing diff
data.body: How can I set VSCode to use diff3 as merge/diff algorithm instead of normal diff? If I show diff in VSCode I have while if I do it from the command line after having configured diff3 as merge tool `git config --global merge.conflictstyle diff3` and having specified that I want `*.cs -text diff=csharp` I get: ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/61557/24699007/ee70f344-19f2-11e7-8782-531f336692fe.png) Is it possible to have the same "semantic" diff behaviour also in VSCode?

data.title: Go to Implementation should be 'Find All Implementations'
data.body: Similar to how we have "Find All References" we should have "Find All Implementation". Today it's aligned with "Go to Definition" but I think its much more likely that I have one definitions of something but many implementations of something. For the same reasons it's called "Find All Referenced" and not "Go to Reference"

data.title: Go to Implementation highlights everything
data.body: * run 'go to implementation' on something that triggers peek/preview * 🐛 the whole things is highlighted not just the name
